subject: [bmcweb] Add BMC Time update logs to the registry
commitMessage:
[bmcweb] Add BMC Time update logs to the registry

Add messages to the OpenBMC registry to log an event that indicates
BMC time is set via NTP, Host or Manually.
During early stage of system boot if any critical events occur,
they are getting logged with 1970 timestamp till the time BMC
time update happens. This is expected behavior, but to call it out
explicitly it is good to log when BMC time is updated.

Tested:
Built and validator passes.
Confirmed that the event is getting logged correctly in Redfish.

Signed-off-by: Joshi-Mansi <mansi.joshi@linux.intel.com>
Change-Id: I402ef59c0a58ddfa376c653f576cac7f8f5dff80

Oh, on that Jason asked for this so I thought parameter thing might be more simpler:
On splitting the messages, I guess we have a third type where the BMC can update its time based on the Host time.  Would we want a third message here for NTP, Manual, and Host or is the parameter simpler?

Anyway, let me divide it for 3 separate messaged and upload it right away.

More background please.
Done, thanks.
whitespace issues.  Please review your own changes in the future.

My bad, directly edited commit msg so missed on spaces.
Won't let it happen again :)
typo.
Ack
Still missing details.  Are there associated patches to push this log?
yes, will update with link
Do we want to differentiate between these two and have a message for each?
Not really, %1 here can specify which one it is.

I'm not as big of a fan of that, because as someone interpreting this log, there's no way to know what %I is going to be.  Considering that (I assume) we need to set this log from two different places, it should be easy to have each have its own message id, which is better for the user, as they can key of each individual one as need be.
I see it the other way, that the user is more likely to want to know when the time was changed, but not why. So it's better to have a converged message.

> I see it the other way, that the user is more likely to want to know when the time was changed, but not why. So it's better to have a converged message.


For the user that cares why how would they know what options are possible?

I would want to know when the time was changed (a bit a of a paradox),
but also at least as importantly is to why it was changed.
    1) Manually
    2) NTP syncing
    3) Time change for the seasons

This is to assist in debugging types of bugs or
security attacks, vulnerabilities, and violations.

Do we want to call this "set" instead of sync?  "sync to manual" isn't really a thing.  Something like

BMC time has been set via NTP
BMC time has been set manually
+1 too
Done, thanks.

Wouldn't it be more useful to log the previous time from just before the update? The event will have an associated timestamp which will be the new time (i think), so putting the new time in the message doesn't add any value. By logging the "previous" time just before the update, we can calculate when the 1970-era events actually happened.

Instead, we can change the message to have extra arg for old time like "BMC Date Time is set to %2 from %3", so that %3 gives the old date time. Wouldn't this be fair enough to know when bmc time set is done and also roll back on old events?
+1. "BMC Date Time is set to %2 from %3" sounds good
+1.  I like it.
+1 ditto
Done, thanks.

Wish we had ArgDescriptions in our registries like Redfish. https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Base.1.9.0.json
Beyond this review, can ignore
ArgDescriptions should be pretty straightforward to add to this.  I'd be in full support if that's something you wanted to add.
sync can be removed from commit message since it was removed from the log message.
BMCTimeUpdated?  Or BMCTimeChanged?
I like either of those better than "done"
Changed to BMCTimeUpdated. Thank you.
Also I though we were going to get rid of sync?

yes, will change it to "Indicates that BMC time is set via NTP/Manual."
Ok?
Done

Considering these are going to be concatenated on the same line, I suspect this can be simplified.  For example, we shouldn't be using the word "BMC" twice.  Really we shouldn't be saying BMC at all, bmc is implied by the fact that this is going to show up in the manager log, not the system log (i realize we break this rule in other places).

I understand. But in web page events are logged generally, so better to mention BMC once.
Below is ok?
"BMC time has been set successfully via %1."
"Date Time is set to %2 from %3.",

"BMC time (changed/updated) via %1. New: %2. Previous: %3.", where (changed/updated) depends on what the MessageId is?

If NTP and Manual are really the only options, we could also have two Messages and eliminate parameter %1.

"But in web page events are logged generally, so better to mention BMC once."

That sounds like a problem in the UI if it makes no differentiation for BMC events and system events.

I think I made the same message suggestion Jason did about splitting the two message types.

I think the issue is we currently only have an "Event Log" for system.  We have the "Journal" log for Managers/bmc but not an event log.  So, we are putting this message into the system event log with the existing event messages.

On splitting the messages, I guess we have a third type where the BMC can update its time based on the Host time.  Would we want a third message here for NTP, Manual, and Host or is the parameter simpler?

I like Ed's suggestion of 2 messages..
Something like: 


BMCTimeUpdatedViaNTP
BMC time has been set via NTP
BMC Date Time is set to %1 from %2.

BMCTimeUPdatedViaManual
BMC time has been set manually
BMC Date Time is set to %1 from %2.
And then third one also where the BMC can update its time based on the Host time as Jason mentioned. So basically 3 messages for logging BMC time update.
Addressed with your suggestion, Gunnar and Ed.
